ratings.comment: Ben Singer is an amazing professor. He is very great at lecturing and keeping your attention. I can't recommend his classes enough.

The lectures were chill and I enjoyed being in the class watching different clips. Yet I don't think I would be able to finish five pages of film analysis during a 3 hours test duration. The test descriptions were very long and took me some time to read through and understand. The expectation is way too high and idk why we need an intense test here

Make sure you watch the films and do the weekly readings and you'll be fine. The lectures can be kind of boring sometimes but he often plays clips so he keeps it interesting in that way. Attendance is required and you fill out a 'code word' every day to be marked present, so make sure you're in class.

I took maybe 7 pages of notes the entire semester. Professor Singer is clearly very intelligent, but he underestimates his students' intelligence. He often spends half of lecture trying to articulate a fairly simple concept. The class could've been taught in 4 weeks. If you are a concise writer, learn to overelaborate or risk getting downgraded.

Professor Singer is a really cool dude. I took Film Comedy with him and hes very passionate about the topic. The lectures can be very dry. He sometimes goes super deep into a topic and rambles for a bit. If it was not for our discussion section I dont think I would have enjoyed the class that much.

Prof Singer is a decent professor, his feedback actually helps students improve their writing. However, he is an extremely slow grader which isn't ideal when your final grade is determined by a handful of projects.

The tough grader tag goes to the grader for this class. Professor Singer himself isn't actually that tough of a grader based on my experience with him in CA 613, but paper and essay exams in 354 are graded by an assistant grader who's rather picky.

I took this class last year and I really enjoyed it. Though some of his lectures could be somewhat verbose, I did admire his unique takes on the topics of discussion. It was clear from taking this course that he was very knowledgeable when it comes to film studies, and his quick wit made the class more enjoyable.

Good lectures, a little verbose, but enjoyable. Singer worked hard to make the content digestible and was flexible with content to work with the class. If you are able to make it to every lecture and take good notes, you'll do just fine. I've taken Singer's classes twice, and have enjoyed both.

This class was on the whole enjoyable. Singer does a good job of elaborating and making his points clear. This class of falls victim to academese (big words for the sake of big words) and often gets lost in verbose lexica. Grading criteria for papers were on the whole really vague, and the TA graded pretty harshly. Slightly above average course.

I really enjoyed Professor Singer, but I understand the controversial status he seems to have on this site. He clearly knows what he's talking about, and really pushes you to think. He is pretty long winded, and can talk pretty much endlessly on something if he wants. However, I really did enjoy the class and Singer's dry humor!

Somehow makes incredibly interesting subject matter the most boring lecture I've taken in 5 years at UW. The attendance app is a chore since it makes you turn on the location to sign into class. Much of his material is dry and repetitive, but if you're a sophomore or junior the information might be useful.

Professor Singer is a funny guy and, for me, learning the theories & patterns of the various film genres was interesting. However, his lectures can be very slow and dry. If you need a super organized & structured professor, reconsider taking this course. Professor Singer tends to be a little vague when it comes to instructions & official due dates.

While the research on film comedy is fairly new, you can tell Professor Singer is fascinated with the topic. Just be prepared for mundane lectures intertwined with a lot of technical terminology and a lot of film clip examples. Tests & papers are easy as long as you study everything off of his Powerpoint slides.

Singer was pretentious, but taught me the curriculum. Lectures are boring and mandatory. He uses an app that tracks your location to see if you actually show up to class. If you get through the boring lectures, the information is easy - but grading is tough.

I have mixed feelings leaving this class... Up until the midterm the course was pretty clear  but the second half and studying for the final was weird. Luckily it was a take home final that takes a little over 6 hours.  The class is basically all about what makes you laugh in various movies. If you go to every lecture and pay attention. easyish A

Enjoyed Film Comedy with Professor Singer, really knows his stuff and how to show clips/movies to make you laugh. Course definitions are confusing with big words, but if you understand the general idea you'll be fine.

This is the first time Singer has taught 313 as a full lecture. So I acknowledge the fact that it's a test run, but it was all over the place. He speaks words but they don't make sense. There was a three question quiz every Thursday. I got by not doing any of the readings, but did a few because they were interesting. Exams were on our computers.
I like him and his lecture content. Because I'm not an English native speaker so sometimes he did use some fancy words but as time went it turned out I'm getting use to him and like him more.

His thought process seem to be different than most professors so he is very confusing and difficult to follow. His instructions on exams are challenging to make sense of and he claims for it to be an "easy class" and then grades exams like a nazi. I would not recommend this professor.
Mean-spirited and dry. He mostly just reads off of his (rather verbose) notes for 50 minutes. Class gets progressively better as the semester goes on, however.

Singer has basically created the taxonomy and categories he teaches in regards to film style and genre with no sense of clarity or order. His logic is very difficult to follow and he fails to follow the models and concepts that you learn in CA350. He seemed like a nice enough guy, but teaching is not his forte. There are better film classes at UW.
Very long and arduous lectures. It's a good topic, but he goes way too in depth with things that have no importance at all. Very unorganized. Really makes the lectures hard to go to.
No Comments
Great class!
Hilarious!
No Comments
Material is interesting but his lectures can get boring sometimes....but he always makes funny jokes.  Explains everything very thoroughly though...I liked having him as a professor
